stream_context.summary: Kaze live-debugs two critical crashes and walks through Biobak’s huge "Dino Dino Domain" overhaul, measuring performance, hunting RAM limits, and planning new gameplay moments.

development_findings.summary: Pressing A one frame before landing crashes the game; disabling Mario’s animation updates stops the crash, indicating an animation pointer/one-frame input buffer issue.
development_findings.quote: There is no way it was the animations, right? It was the animations? Yes! What is happening?

development_findings.summary: Importing the new Dino Dino Domain build exceeded RAM by about 1 KB; removing an unused ‘leaf boat’ texture and enabling “bleed & inline” freed enough space for the level to load.
development_findings.quote: We were using literally one kilobyte of memory too much in this level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze now compiles with extremely strict warning flags and has driven the codebase to "zero warnings."
New vine-jump system automatically rotates Mario toward the next vine and auto-catches on A-press, simplifying control for newcomers.
Added an overworld save-block that appears after exiting a level; intended as psychological reinforcement even though the game already auto-saves.
development_findings.quote: This is about psychology. I already know people will hit the save block three times before turning the game off.

development_findings.summary: Plans to replace Fast64’s 30 FPS texture scroll with an engine-level 60 FPS version for smoother waterfalls and nightclub lights.
Measured Dino Dino Domain performance at ~22.5 FPS worst-case with AA; Biobak’s visual pass costs ~1.5–2 FPS; occlusion planes are considered to claw frames back.
Uses an unreleased Nemu64 build plus Project64 and C/assembly mix for low-level debugging.
Concept approved: Star sits inside the nightclub disco ball; when Mario grabs the pole, the ball snaps, falls, shatters, and the room goes dark—Shy Guy stops dancing.
development_findings.quote: You would really feel the impact of your actions.

context_findings.summary: Upgraded to Windows 11 last week for security reasons; reinstalling toolchain and dealing with VS Code quirks.
Frustrated by viewers claiming an AI voice was used in his latest video; clarifies it’s just Joshua’s British accent.
context_findings.quote: People keep complaining that there is an AI voice in my video when it’s just how Joshua sounds.

context_findings.summary: Design philosophy: multiple, obvious tutorials (e.g., wall-kick) and visible feedback loops to help players new to Mario 64 mechanics.
Emotional arc: visible excitement over Biobak’s art improvements, relief after memory crash fix, and annoyance with GIMP, ShadowPlay and long debug sessions.

biobak.summary: Delivered a major Dino Dino Domain art/level pass: new transparent water, rounded pillars, moss overlays, redesigned bridges, nightclub set dressing, Yoshi-statue hieroglyphs and reduced polygon counts.
biobak.quote: Alright, we’re gonna get a big DinoDino Domain rework today.

biobak.summary: Detailed changelog helped Kaze systematically review and flag technical issues (overdraw, triple-layered waterfalls, decal order).

zeina.summary: Creating neon sign assets for the retro section of Course 15; Kaze plans to reuse the nightclub combiner techniques.
zeina.quote: Zeina’s making a lot of these for the retro section of Course 15, so that’s gonna be sweet.

key_stories.title: The One-Frame Input Crash
key_stories.summary: A mysterious crash occurs when players press A the frame before landing. Live on stream, Kaze traces it through assembly registers and discovers that disabling animations removes the bug.
key_stories.challenge: Game crashes on specific frame-perfect input.
key_stories.process: Used Nemu64 debugger to follow register changes, compared emulator behaviors, and toggled subsystems until the crash disappeared.
key_stories.outcome: Identified animation system as the trigger; root cause still to be coded.
key_stories.key_quote: There is no way it was the animations, right? It was the animations? Yes!

key_stories.title: 1 KB From Disaster
key_stories.summary: Biobak’s upgraded Course 2 wouldn’t load; Kaze dug into memory pools and found the ROM was over budget by a single kilobyte.
key_stories.challenge: Level import crashed at load-area terrain stage.
key_stories.process: Stepped through segment loading code, confirmed out-of-memory assert, freed space by deleting an unused texture and enabling inline/bleed packing.
key_stories.outcome: Level now boots, highlighting razor-thin N64 limits.
key_stories.key_quote: We were using literally one kilobyte of memory too much in this level.

key_stories.title: Stealing the Beat
key_stories.summary: While reviewing the nightclub area, chat and Kaze craft a moment where the star powers the disco ball. When stolen, the club shuts down, leaving Shy Guys in silence.
key_stories.challenge: Make star collection in the nightclub memorable.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed live, mapped required animation, lighting and AI state changes.
key_stories.outcome: New scripted sequence slated for implementation.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine the star is inside the disco ball and as soon as you steal it, the entire room goes dark.
